Pollution modeling enhances our ability to combat climate change. Scientists rely on pollution models to provide critical data for emissions management, climate predictions, health protection, and sustainable energy planning. Traditionally, pollution simulations use numerical methods, such as the finite element method, finite difference method, finite volume method, and computational fluid dynamics, to solve partial differential equations (PDEs) that describe physical laws. However, these methods are slow, taking days to run.

Recent advances in machine learning have led to the development of physics-informed neural networks (PINNs), which can potentially offer a faster alternative to traditional numerical methods. PINNs have been successfully trained to solve PDEs, including the Navier-Stokes equations, which describe fluid flow. Neural networks are theoretically capable of approximating any continuous function, making them a promising technology that can render traditional numerical methods obsolete.

In recent years, researchers have used PINNs to model pollution spread under various conditions. However, most of these studies have focused on solving PDEs on a continuous grid without incorporating obstructions. Our research aims to address this limitation by introducing obstructions and incorporating soft initial conditions into the model.

We developed a PINN that integrates the Navier-Stokes and advection-diffusion PDEs and enforces no-slip and zero-flux Neumann boundaries at obstruction surfaces and simulation edges. We used a hybrid learning approach, generating a dataset of 16.1 million colocation points for supervised learning and embedding physical laws into the loss function for unsupervised learning.

Our experiments showed that the PINN was over 2520 times faster than traditional numerical solvers for 5000 timesteps, delivering results in under 2190 milliseconds and achieving a mean squared error below 3E-5. Our findings demonstrate that PINNs offer a drastic reduction in computational time and scale favorably with both the time domain and spatial resolution, making them a viable solution for real-time pollution monitoring and emergency response planning.

Future work will focus on extending our model to dynamic obstructions and arbitrary grid geometries. Our model can simulate pollution spread from any given source location, making it a valuable tool for pollution management and mitigation.

The spread of pollution is governed by the Navier-Stokes and advection-diffusion PDEs. Numerical simulations for pollution spread consist of two general steps: solving for fluid flow and advecting the pollutant particles. We model pollution in a 2D 100 x 100 Cartesian grid for timesteps in the range [0, 5000], assuming laminar flow throughout. We apply no-slip and zero-flux Neumann boundary conditions along obstruction surfaces and the edges of the simulation environment to ensure no pollutant flux occurs across boundaries.

The initial pollutant source location and concentration are programmed into our spatial grid using an exponential function. Our model can simulate pollution spread from any given source location, making it a valuable tool for pollution management and mitigation.
